items.content_html:
Summary

Motivation

I've noticed that there's a bit misnomer when we say "the let statement", because let is a declaration. I'm relieved that "statements & declarations" are part of the same category, so no bigger refactoring needed, but I still decided to make the wording clearer.

Supporting details

Motivation

items.title: Options description of toLocaleString()

items.content_html:
Summary

Motivation

Fix #3748.

The entire section is a bit misleading: I'd say it's not even wrong™! It's trying to assign ocn.prototype, but ocn is an object, not a constructor, so we need to assign ocn.__proto__ instead. The notion of "standard object" is also weird, because Object is nothing but a collection of object methods, and the fact that Object.__proto__.__proto__ is Object.prototype doesn't make it any more special than {}. I decided, in the end, that this section is just completely barking up the wrong tree and should be removed.

I improved the clarity of the rest of the explanation to make it clearer what we are doing.

Supporting details

Related issues

Metadata

  • Adds a new document
  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document
  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error
items.title: Remove "NON-solutions" about adding object methods in Object.create

items.content_html:
Summary

Firstly, a period is moved outside the link, as it shouldn't be a part of it. Secondly, a period is removed from the end of the list item under the "Setting values" subsection to make it consistent with other adjacent list items. Also the blank line between the two sentences contained in that list item is removed to match the display on the actual website. Lastly, a period at the end of the first list item under the "See also" section is also removed for the sake of consistency. Note that the last mentioned problem is present on many pages, for the most part there are no periods at the end of the list items across the website below the "See also" section, but there are also many cases where a period is inconsistently included in the same way as here. Please let me know if that should be fixed or left as it is.

Motivation

Supporting details

Related issues

Clear up an obvious grammatical error. We are only as good as we can communicate. Nothing is more frustrating that documentation that isn't properly written.

See above. The comma would only be used for an interjection or a list denominator; this was an inappropriate use of a comma.

items.title: Grammar

items.content_html:
Summary

Removes the spaces and line breaks between the <li> elements
in the horizontal nav menu example.

Motivation

As noted in the the tutorial's text, there must be no spaces or line spaces
between the <li> elements.

Otherwise, the fifth item ("Finland") ends up being placed
on a line by itself, contrary to the intended nav menu design.

Supporting details

https://css-tricks.com/fighting-the-space-between-inline-block-elements/

Related issues

items.content_html:
Summary

I couldn't find any description on how to add the onclick handler directly on a target HTML element. I thought it might be useful to include it here.

Motivation

I was looking over a stackoverflow question regarding click handlers, when I came to MDN for more information I could not find any reference on how to add the onclick handler directly on to a target HTML element.

Supporting details

addEventListener vs onclick - Stack Overflow
EventTarget.addEventListener() - Web APIs | MDN

items.title: Add inline onclick description

items.content_html:
This change replaces a number of the last remaining manual Specifications tables with {{Specifications}} macros calls — for cases where the article cited multiple BCD features and multiple spec URLs. So this patch uses browser-compat keys with YAML array values to supply the data necessary for generating the Browser Compatibility and Specifications sections.

Because this change requires Yari support for processing YAML arrays in the browser-compat key, this is blocked on mdn/yari#6004
items.title: Replace manual spec tables in API tree (using browser-compat arrays)

Mostly bad capitalization + in the mozilla/mdn trees (the others were already done).
items.title: Fix redirected/broken links

items.content_html:
Summary

Added a note that xlink:href may be included in addition to href to support older browsers.

Motivation

We recently tried removing xlink:href from an svg sprite we use for our site, and found that it broke the sprite for users on Safari < 12.1, as specified by the browser support table. Looking at our analytics, this only comprises a portion of a single percent of our users - but this is still over a thousand users a week. Therefore, it seems worthwhile to note that both attributes may be included, which allows rendering on Safari < 12.1, but also future-proofs against browsers dropping support for xlink:href.

Supporting details

Note that this is supported in the W3 SVG2 spec here:

When the ‘href’ attribute is present in both the XLink namespace and without a namespace, the value of the attribute without a namespace shall be used. The attribute in the XLink namespace shall be ignored.

Related issues

I proposed this same change to the href page: #16241

Metadata

  • Adds a new document
  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document
  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error
items.title: Noting xlink:href fallback option to support older browsers

items.title: Viewport Meta: add property definitions. Remove legacy.

items.content_html:
Replaces class for loop with for...of.

Motivation

The classical for loop would work in more browsers, but is harder to read. When I read the example, I also wondered why it started from the end of the list instead of the beginning, which added a layer of confusion.

Supporting details

I don't have any, but I would like

  • the NamedNodeMap document to say something about how/why for...of works for this interface. Maybe it could say that it implements Symbol.iterator and thus indicate that Element.attributes can/should use for..of?
  • some document that says something along the lines of "for...of is more modern" than classic for loops?

Relevant Links

  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Statements/for...of
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/attributes
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/NamedNodeMap

Related issues

N/A

items.content_html:
https://drafts.csswg.org/css-text-decor/#text-decoration-property

text-decoration-thickness is not part of the shorthand.
including it will make the declaration fail in safari.

Also, blink is deprecated as a text-decoration-style, and since it renders as none in most browsers, killed it as an example.

Summary

Motivation

Supporting details
